reasoning: The critique targets a real vulnerability: several examples in §2.3 (especially §2.3.4) are framed as selectable institutional “dials,” while in practice policy choices are constrained by strategic behavior and equilibrium selection. If true, this would shift the story from “many accidental moral flaws are easy” to “many bad outcomes are incentive-stable,” which changes how plausible/tractable certain “avoid moral catastrophe” routes are. However, this is only moderately central to the essay’s core thesis (that near-best futures are a narrow target and value is fragile/multiplicative across many dimensions). Even if the author conceded that these regimes are equilibrium outcomes, that largely reinforces (or at least leaves intact) the claim that getting to mostly-great futures is hard by default; it undercuts some illustrative framing, not the main multiplicative/fussiness argument in §3. Strength is moderate because the critique doesn’t show that the essay’s conclusion is false, only that one class of examples is underspecified and perhaps mis-modeled as choice rather than constraint. Correctness is fairly high: identity/shelling incentives and racing-to-claim dynamics are standard, though the critique overgeneralizes by implying the paper ‘repeatedly’ treats such issues as fully controllable and that catastrophes ‘systematically understate’ manipulation across the board. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Policy choices are presented as moral dials but will collapse into exploitative equilibria
